abstract.p: A 29-year-old female was diagnosed to have adult-type anomalous left coronary artery from pulmonary artery (ALCAPA). She underwent a two-coronary system repair using left internal mammary artery and right internal mammary artery Y (LIMA-RIMA Y) off-pump coronary artery bypass grafting and made an uneventful postoperative recovery. The usage of off-pump LIMA-RIMA Y graft can be a suitable option for adult ALCAPA with a potential for good long-term outcomes.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Anomalous left coronary artery from pulmonary artery (ALCAPA) is a rare congenital anomaly that can present as either infantile or adult type. Repairs that establish a two-coronary system are preferred; however, the choice among multiple options available for a two-coronary system repair depends on the presentation and anatomy.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 29-year-old female from Republic of Tanzania presented with chest pain and breathlessness from schooldays. She was diagnosed as having a patent ductus arteriosus in childhood and was untreated. Her clinical examination was unremarkable except for a continuous murmur in second left intercostal space. On evaluation, the left coronary artery was found to arise anomalously from the pulmonary artery. Computed tomography coronary angiogram (Figure 1) revealed the left main coronary artery (LMCA) originating from the nonfacing sinus of the main pulmonary artery. The right and left coronary arteries were dilated and tortuous with multiple collaterals on the epicardium and through the interventricular septum. There was retrograde flow from the left coronary artery to the pulmonary artery. There was evidence of focal linear areas of nonenhancing hypodensity in the subendocardial area of the lateral wall of the left ventricle and the papillary muscles, suggestive of chronic ischemia/infarction. Electrocardiogram was normal, and echocardiogram revealed normal ventricular function, no regional wall motion abnormalities, and no mitral regurgitation.

caption.p: Computed tomography coronary angiogram showing dilated right coronary artery and transseptal collaterals.

sec.p: A two-coronary system repair, with ligation of the left main coronary at its origin from the pulmonary artery and coronary artery bypass grafting using skeletonized left internal mammary artery (LIMA) and right internal mammary artery (RIMA) Y graft (LIMA-to-left anterior descending [LAD] and RIMA-to-ramus intermedius), was done off-pump. The patient made an uneventful postoperative recovery and was discharged on the seventh postoperative day. She remains symptom free at short-term follow-up. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first reported case where the LIMA and RIMA were used as a Y graft for off-pump revascularization in a patient with ALCAPA.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The ALCAPA is a rare congenital anomaly, which usually presents during childhood and is associated with high early mortality. 1 Occasionally, a patient with extensive collaterals and possibly a restrictive communication to the pulmonary artery present in adulthood. 1 The diagnosis of ALCAPA is an indication for repair at any age, and a repair that establishes a two-coronary system is considered superior to single-coronary system repair. 1

In adults, revascularizing the coronary arteries using arterial grafts may be the more preferred approach for several reasons. The bigger size of conduits and coronaries makes bypass grafting easier than in infants and small children. An off-pump technique avoids the need for cardiopulmonary bypass. Moreover, it avoids the difficulties in cardioplegia delivery and possible incomplete myocardial protection owing to the coronary steal existing in ALCAPA. In addition, coronary revascularization using internal mammary artery (IMA) has been successfully used for the treatment of ALCAPA in both adults and children, 2,3 while the superiority of the mammary artery over vein grafts is proven. Direct reimplantation of the ALCAPA may be technically more difficult and hazardous in adults because of increased coronary artery friability, diminished vessel elasticity for mobilization, and the potential for tearing. 4 In cases like this with LMCA originating from the nonfacing pulmonary sinus, direct transfer is unsuitable and a tunnel repair as described by Takeuchi et al 5 is more complex and may be associated with pulmonary artery obstruction. 4

We preferred left and right IMAs to the LAD and the ramus intermedius branch, as this arrangement provides antegrade flow to both the anterior and the lateral walls. Ligation of the LMCA always carries the risk of kinking the left main bifurcation, making separate grafts to anterior and lateral walls a safer option. We used LIMA-RIMA Y grafting, as it is our institutional practice for total arterial revascularization, and such an arrangement helps the RIMA to reach the left side of heart easily. However, the RIMA can be brought as an in situ graft to the left side of the heart through the transverse sinus, with or without retrocaval positioning. This is another attractive option in a case like this, as the in situ method of IMA grafting may have superior patency rates compared with free IMA grafts. 6 Another strategy is RIMA-to-LAD and LIMA-to-oblique marginal/ramus intermedius technique; however, this has the risk of damaging the RIMA graft during subsequent reoperations. Use of LIMA radial Y and bilateral pedicled IMA has been previously reported for ALCAPA. 7,2 We preferred a LIMA-RIMA Y graft over the LIMA and radial artery Y graft, as recent evidence suggests that the RIMA could possibly be superior compared to radial artery as a conduit, 8 and a forearm incision is eliminated. Another potential disadvantage of using a LIMA-RIMA Y could be the argument that the blood supply from a Y graft may not be sufficient for the anterior and lateral wall. However, the successful usage of Y grafting in coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) could negate this argument.

Additionally, the usage of an off-pump technique has all the intrinsic disadvantages of off-pump CABG. The chances of intraoperative ischemia and ventricular fibrillation are possibly greater in the setting of ALCAPA, as the myocardium is already ischemic. Overall, the patency rates of off-pump CABG are comparable to on-pump CABG. However, some authors have reported lesser patency rates for off-pump CABG, compared to on-pump. Hence, an off-pump technique in ALCAPA is advisable only in centers with adequate experience in off-pump technique. Usage of a shunt during anastomosis and keeping an assembled heart lung bypass pump ready on standby adds to the safety. On-pump beating heart technique is another useful option, which also avoids the need for cardioplegia delivery.

sec.title: Comment
sec.p: The diagnosis of ALCAPA is an indication for surgery. A two-coronary system repair is preferable to single-coronary system repair. The CABG may be more preferable in adults and can be performed off-pump. Combined LIMA and RIMA grafting provides antegrade flow to both anterior and lateral walls with potential for good long-term outcomes. Usage of Y grafting technique helps the RIMA to reach the lateral wall with ease. Off-pump technique avoids the need for cardiopulmonary bypass and cardioplegia delivery in such cases.
